prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 setup 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
ID Trans. z Obs. Freq. GS_IRS33 CO:3-2 2.14 110.126 GS_IRS81 CO:3-2 2.55 97.407
Note we set the spectral windows by hand in order to cover the relevant lines for all sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Background: We propose CO measurements of 17 unique high redshift galaxies for which we have existing deep mid-IR spectroscopy, allowing us to probe the underlying radiation field and the conditions of the ISM. During the cryogenic lifetime of Spitzer, ~350 sources were observed with the IRS in the GOODS/ECDFS/xFLS fields. We have reduced all of these data in a consistent way using our locally developed pipeline optimized for faint extragalactic sources to create a large library of mid-IR spectroscopy at z~0.5-3. From the parent population, we select 17 sources spanning a range of spectral properties, including strongly star forming galaxies and AGN, allowing us to quantify how an AGN affects the ISM of the host galaxy.
Expected Source Properties: Science Goal 1 will be used to observe the J(3-2) transition for 2 sources, GS_IRS33 and GS_IRS81. We have been careful in estimating our sensitivity. With the plethora of far-IR/submm data in this field, we have done detailed SED fitting to obtain very accurate measurements of LIR. Given the range of LIR/LCO ratios seen in high redshift galaxies, LCO can be estimated from LIR assuming a conversion factor for submillimeter galaxies, which are primarily mergers, or for normal star forming galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013). Our galaxies exhibit a mix of merger and disk-like morphologies, and they do not have LIRs typical of submillimeter galaxies, so we average the two conversion factors together to calculate the expected LCO. We then use the most current ratios (Carilli & Walter 2013) to convert between J(1-0) and J(3-2). We assume a CO line width of 200 km/s which is consistent with that of other star forming galaxies at these redshifts (e.g., Tacconi et al. 2010; Daddi et al. 2010). We aim for a 5 sigma detection of the peak line flux to ensure that we are able to make accurate measurements of the CO luminosity. The OT estimates 46 minutes, including overheads. In summary, we calculate: GS_IRS33 CO(3-2) peak line flux: 2.8 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.6 mJy GS_IRS81 CO(3-2) peak line flux: 5.2 mJy 5sigma rms: 1.0 mJy
Observational Setup: For this Science Goal, we will observe 2 sources in Band 3. We have arranged the spectral windows by hand to cover the relevant lines (97.41 GHz and 110.13 GHz), and we place the 2 remaining windows accordingly so as to maximize the continuum sensitivity. Compact configuration (~5” resolution) is sufficient as we do not wish to resolve the CO emission, and this resolution matches the resolution of our Spitzer IRS spectra. We choose the system-defined calibration.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 setup 2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
ID Trans. z Obs. Freq. GS_IRS53 CO:3-2 2.45 100.231 GS_IRS4 CO:2-1 1.30 100.234 GS_IRS15 CO:3-2 2.11 111.118 GS_IRS35 CO:2-1 1.04 113.009 GS_IRS47 CO:2-1 1.04 113.009
Note we set the spectral windows by hand in order to cover the relevant lines for all sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Background: We propose CO measurements of 17 unique high redshift galaxies for which we have existing deep mid-IR spectroscopy, allowing us to probe the underlying radiation field and the conditions of the ISM. During the cryogenic lifetime of Spitzer, ~350 sources were observed with the IRS in the GOODS/ECDFS/xFLS fields. We have reduced all of these data in a consistent way using our locally developed pipeline optimized for faint extragalactic sources to create a large library of mid-IR spectroscopy at z~0.5-3. From the parent population, we select 17 sources spanning a range of spectral properties, including strongly star forming galaxies and AGN, allowing us to quantify how an AGN affects the ISM of the host galaxy.
Expected Source Properties: Science Goal 2 will be used to observe 5 sources, GS_IRS4, GS_IRS15, GS_IRS35, GS_IRS47 and GS_IRS53. For 2 of the objects, we will observe the J(3-2) transition, and the remaining objects have redshifts such that we will observe the J(2-1) transition. We have been careful in estimating our sensitivity. With the plethora of far-IR/submm data in this field, we have done detailed SED fitting to obtain very accurate measurements of LIR. Given the range of LIR/LCO ratios seen in high redshift galaxies, LCO can be estimated from LIR assuming a conversion factor for submillimeter galaxies, which are primarily mergers, or for normal star forming galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013). Our galaxies exhibit a mix of merger and disk-like morphologies, and they do not have LIRs typical of submillimeter galaxies, so we average the two conversion factors together to calculate the expected LCO. We then use the most current ratios (Carilli & Walter 2013) to convert between J(1-0) and J(2-1) or J(3-2). We assume a CO line width of 200 km/s which is consistent with that of other star forming galaxies at these redshifts (e.g., Tacconi et al. 2010; Daddi et al. 2010). We aim for a 5 sigma detection of the peak line flux to ensure that we are able to make accurate measurements of the CO luminosity. The OT estimates 2 hours 44 minutes, including overheads. In summary, we calculate: GS_IRS4 CO(2-1) peak line flux: 6.3 mJy 5sigma rms: 1.3 mJy GS_IRS15 CO(3-2) peak line flux: 1.8 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.4 mJy GS_IRS35 CO(2-1) peak line flux: 2.8 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.6 mJy GS_IRS47 CO(2-1) peak line flux: 2.5 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.5 mJy GS_IRS53 CO(3-2) peak line flux: 1.9 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.4 mJy
Observational Setup: For this Science Goal, we will observe 5 sources in Band 3. We have arranged the spectral windows by hand to cover the relevant lines (100.23 GHz, 111.19 GHz, and 113.01 GHz), and we place the remaining window accordingly so as to maximize the continuum sensitivity. Compact configuration (~5” resolution) is sufficient as we do not wish to resolve the CO emission, and this resolution matches the resolution of our Spitzer IRS spectra. We choose the system-defined calibration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Background: We propose CO measurements of 17 unique high redshift galaxies for which we have existing deep mid-IR spectroscopy, allowing us to probe the underlying radiation field and the conditions of the ISM. During the cryogenic lifetime of Spitzer, ~350 sources were observed with the IRS in the GOODS/ECDFS/xFLS fields. We have reduced all of these data in a consistent way using our locally developed pipeline optimized for faint extragalactic sources to create a large library of mid-IR spectroscopy at z~0.5-3. From the parent population, we select 17 sources spanning a range of spectral properties, including strongly star forming galaxies and AGN, allowing us to quantify how an AGN affects the ISM of the host galaxy.
Expected Source Properties: Science Goal 3 will be used to observe the J(3-2) transition for 2 sources, GS_IRS1 and GS_IRS38. We have been careful in estimating our sensitivity. With the plethora of far-IR/submm data in this field, we have done detailed SED fitting to obtain very accurate measurements of LIR. Given the range of LIR/LCO ratios seen in high redshift galaxies, LCO can be estimated from LIR assuming a conversion factor for submillimeter galaxies, which are primarily mergers, or for normal star forming galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013). Our galaxies exhibit a mix of merger and disk-like morphologies, and they do not have LIRs typical of submillimeter galaxies, so we average the two conversion factors together to calculate the expected LCO. We then use the most current ratios (Carilli & Walter 2013) to convert between J(1-0) and J(3-2). We aim for a 5 sigma detection of the peak line flux to ensure that we are able to make accurate measurements of the CO luminosity. The OT estimates 53 minutes, including overheads. In summary, we calculate: GS_IRS1 CO(3-2) peak line flux: 2.4 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.5 mJy GS_IRS38 CO(3-2) peak line flux: 4.2 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.8 mJy

We have arranged the spectral windows by hand to cover the relevant lines (93.71 GHz and 104.79 GHz), and we place the remaining windows accordingly so as to maximize the continuum sensitivity. Compact configuration (~5” resolution) is sufficient as we do not wish to resolve the CO emission, and this resolution matches the resolution of our Spitzer IRS spectra. We choose the system-defined calibration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Background: We propose CO measurements of 17 unique high redshift galaxies for which we have existing deep mid-IR spectroscopy, allowing us to probe the underlying radiation field and the conditions of the ISM. During the cryogenic lifetime of Spitzer, ~350 sources were observed with the IRS in the GOODS/ECDFS/xFLS fields. We have reduced all of these data in a consistent way using our locally developed pipeline optimized for faint extragalactic sources to create a large library of mid-IR spectroscopy at z~0.5-3. From the parent population, we select 17 sources spanning a range of spectral properties, including strongly star forming galaxies and AGN, allowing us to quantify how an AGN affects the ISM of the host galaxy.
Expected Source Properties: Science Goal 4 will be used to observe 3 sources, GS_IRS13, GS_IRS45, and GS_IRS38. GS_IRS13 and GS_IRS45 are at the same redshift, and we will observe the J(3-2) transition, while GS_IRS63 is at a lower redshift, so we can observe the J(2-1) transition. We have been careful in estimating our sensitivity. With the plethora of far-IR/submm data in this field, we have done detailed SED fitting to obtain very accurate measurements of LIR. Given the range of LIR/LCO ratios seen in high redshift galaxies, LCO can be estimated from LIR assuming a conversion factor for submillimeter galaxies, which are primarily mergers, or for normal star forming galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013). Our galaxies exhibit a mix of merger and disk-like morphologies, and they do not have LIRs typical of submillimeter galaxies, so we average the two conversion factors together to calculate the expected LCO. We then use the most current ratios (Carilli & Walter 2013) to convert between J(1-0) and J(2-1) or J(3-2). We assume a CO line width of 200 km/s which is consistent with that of other star forming galaxies at these redshifts (e.g., Tacconi et al. 2010; Daddi et al. 2010). We aim for a 5 sigma detection of the peak line flux to ensure that we are able to make accurate measurements of the CO luminosity. The OT estimates 56 minutes, including overheads. In summary, we calculate: GS_IRS13 CO(3-2) peak line flux: 4.2 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.8 mJy GS_IRS34 CO(3-2) peak line flux: 7.9 mJy 5sigma rms: 1.6 mJy GS_IRS63 CO(2-1) peak line flux: 2.3 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.5 mJy
Observational Setup: For this Science Goal, we will observe 3 sources in Band 4. We have arranged the spectral windows by hand to cover the relevant lines (131.98 GHz and 132.49 GHz), and we place the remaining windows accordingly so as to maximize the continuum sensitivity. Compact configuration (~5” resolution) is sufficient as we do not wish to resolve the CO emission, and this resolution matches the resolution of our Spitzer IRS spectra. We choose the system-defined calibration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Background: We propose CO measurements of 17 unique high redshift galaxies for which we have existing deep mid-IR spectroscopy, allowing us to probe the underlying radiation field and the conditions of the ISM. During the cryogenic lifetime of Spitzer, ~350 sources were observed with the IRS in the GOODS/ECDFS/xFLS fields. We have reduced all of these data in a consistent way using our locally developed pipeline optimized for faint extragalactic sources to create a large library of mid-IR spectroscopy at z~0.5-3. From the parent population, we select 17 sources spanning a range of spectral properties, including strongly star forming galaxies and AGN, allowing us to quantify how an AGN affects the ISM of the host galaxy.
Expected Source Properties: Science Goal 5 will be used to observe 2 sources, GS_IRS5 and GS_IRS8. We will observe the J(3-2) transition in GS_IRS8 and J(2-1) in GS_IRS5. We have been careful in estimating our sensitivity. With the plethora of far-IR/submm data in this field, we have done detailed SED fitting to obtain very accurate measurements of LIR. Given the range of LIR/LCO ratios seen in high redshift galaxies, LCO can be estimated from LIR assuming a conversion factor for submillimeter galaxies, which are primarily mergers, or for normal star forming galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013). Our galaxies exhibit a mix of merger and disk-like morphologies, and they do not have LIRs typical of submillimeter galaxies, so we average the two conversion factors together to calculate the expected LCO. We then use the most current ratios (Carilli & Walter 2013) to convert between J(1-0) and J(2-1) or J(3-2). We assume a CO line width of 200 km/s which is consistent with that of other star forming galaxies at these redshifts (e.g., Tacconi et al. 2010; Daddi et al. 2010). We aim for a 5 sigma detection of the peak line flux to ensure that we are able to make accurate measurements of the CO luminosity. The OT estimates 27 minutes, including overheads. In summary, we calculate: GS_IRS5 CO(2-1) peak line flux: 17.3 mJy 5sigma rms: 3.5 mJy GS_IRS8 CO(3-2) peak line flux: 11.0 mJy 5sigma rms: 2.2 mJy
Observational Setup: For this Science Goal, we will observe 3 sources in Band 4. We have arranged the spectral windows by hand to cover the relevant lines (134.03 GHz and 135.61 GHz), and we place the remaining windows accordingly so as to maximize the continuum sensitivity. Compact configuration (~5” resolution) is sufficient as we do not wish to resolve the CO emission, and this resolution matches the resolution of our Spitzer IRS spectra. We choose the system-defined calibration

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Background: We propose CO measurements of 17 unique high redshift galaxies for which we have existing deep mid-IR spectroscopy, allowing us to probe the underlying radiation field and the conditions of the ISM. During the cryogenic lifetime of Spitzer, ~350 sources were observed with the IRS in the GOODS/ECDFS/xFLS fields. We have reduced all of these data in a consistent way using our locally developed pipeline optimized for faint extragalactic sources to create a large library of mid-IR spectroscopy at z~0.5-3. From the parent population, we select 17 sources spanning a range of spectral properties, including strongly star forming galaxies and AGN, allowing us to quantify how an AGN affects the ISM of the host galaxy.
Expected Source Properties: Science Goal 6 will be used to observe 4 sources, GS_IRS3, GS_IRS4, GS_IRS6, and GS_IRS73. We will observe the J(2-1) transition in GS_IRS3, GS_IRS6, and GS_IRS73. For GS_IRS4, we will observe the J(3-2) transition, and we are also observing the J(2-1) transition for this source in Science Goal 2, so that we can calibrate converting between the J(2-1) and J(3-2) transitions for our sources. We have been careful in estimating our sensitivity. With the plethora of far-IR/submm data in this field, we have done detailed SED fitting to obtain very accurate measurements of LIR. Given the range of LIR/LCO ratios seen in high redshift galaxies, LCO can be estimated from LIR assuming a conversion factor for submillimeter galaxies, which are primarily mergers, or for normal star forming galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013). Our galaxies exhibit a mix of merger and disk-like morphologies, and they do not have LIRs typical of submillimeter galaxies, so we average the two conversion factors together to calculate the expected LCO. We then use the most current ratios (Carilli & Walter 2013) to convert between J(1-0) and J(2-1) or J(3-2). We assume a CO line width of 200 km/s which is consistent with that of other star forming galaxies at these redshifts (e.g., Tacconi et al. 2010; Daddi et al. 2010). We aim for a 5 sigma detection of the peak line flux to ensure that we are able to make accurate measurements of the CO luminosity. The OT estimates 2 hours 2 minutes, including overheads. In summary, we calculate: GS_IRS3 CO(2-1) peak line flux: 2.2 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.4 mJy GS_IRS4 CO(3-2) peak line flux: 9.4 mJy 5sigma rms: 1.9 mJy GS_IRS6 CO(2-1) peak line flux: 2.8 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.6 mJy GS_IRS73 CO(2-1) peak line flux: 1.9 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.4 mJy
Observational Setup: For this Science Goal, we will observe 4 sources in Band 4. We have arranged the spectral windows by hand to cover the relevant lines (138.05 GHz, 148.73 GHz, and 150.35 GHz), and we place the remaining window accordingly so as to maximize the continuum sensitivity. Compact configuration (~5” resolution) is sufficient as we do not wish to resolve the CO emission, and this resolution matches the resolution of our Spitzer IRS spectra. We choose the system-defined calibration.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Background: We propose CO measurements of 17 unique high redshift galaxies for which we have existing deep mid-IR spectroscopy, allowing us to probe the underlying radiation field and the conditions of the ISM. During the cryogenic lifetime of Spitzer, ~350 sources were observed with the IRS in the GOODS/ECDFS/xFLS fields. We have reduced all of these data in a consistent way using our locally developed pipeline optimized for faint extragalactic sources to create a large library of mid-IR spectroscopy at z~0.5-3. From the parent population, we select 17 sources spanning a range of spectral properties, including strongly star forming galaxies and AGN, allowing us to quantify how an AGN affects the ISM of the host galaxy.
Expected Source Properties: Science Goal 7 will be used to observe the J(2-1) transition in 2 sources, GS_IRS13 and GS_IRS45. We are also observing the J(3-2) transition for this source in Science Goal 4, so that we can calibrate converting between the J(2-1) and J(3-2) transitions for our sources. We have been careful in estimating our sensitivity. With the plethora of far-IR/submm data in this field, we have done detailed SED fitting to obtain very accurate measurements of LIR. Given the range of LIR/LCO ratios seen in high redshift galaxies, LCO can be estimated from LIR assuming a conversion factor for submillimeter galaxies, which are primarily mergers, or for normal star forming galaxies (Carilli & Walter 2013). Our galaxies exhibit a mix of merger and disk-like morphologies, and they do not have LIRs typical of submillimeter galaxies, so we average the two conversion factors together to calculate the expected LCO. We then use the most current ratios (Carilli & Walter 2013) to convert between J(1-0) and J(2-1). We assume a CO line width of 200 km/s which is consistent with that of other star forming galaxies at these redshifts (e.g., Tacconi et al. 2010; Daddi et al. 2010). We aim for a 5 sigma detection of the peak line flux to ensure that we are able to make accurate measurements of the CO luminosity. The OT estimates 45 minutes, including overheads. In summary, we calculate: GS_IRS13 CO(2-1) peak line flux: 2.8 mJy 5sigma rms: 0.6 mJy GS_IRS45 CO(2-1) peak line flux: 5.3 mJy 5sigma rms: 1.1 mJy
Observational Setup: For this Science Goal, we will observe 2 sources in Band 3. These sources are at the same redshift, so we have arranged the spectral windows by hand to cover the relevant line (87.99 GHz), and we place the remaining windows accordingly so as to maximize the continuum sensitivity. Compact configuration (~5” resolution) is sufficient as we do not wish to resolve the CO emission, and this resolution matches the resolution of our Spitzer IRS spectra. We choose the system-defined calibration.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
The bulk of stellar mass in the Universe was formed from z=1-3, a time when many galaxies were also actively feeding their central black holes. The relationships between the dust, gas, star formation, and active galactic nuclei (AGN) are not well understood, and we aim to probe these relationships in a unique sample of 17 high-z, dusty, luminous galaxies.
We propose CO observations, which we will complement with existing ancillary data, including priceless Spitzer mid-IR spectroscopy and far-IR imaging data. With the crucial mid-IR spectra, we quantify the contributions to the dust heating from AGN and star formaton, and we can probe the inner regions of PDRs by tracing PAH emission. Our far-IR imaging enables us to accurately constrain LIR and the star formation rate. With the pivotal knowledge of the molecular gas, we can constrain the effect an AGN has on star formation efficiency (LIR/LCO) in the host galaxy, and we can determine the relationship between the PAHs and the molecular gas, expected to be cospatial within star forming regions. The AGN we will study reside in typical galaxies at these redshifts, making them distinct from the previous CO studies of luminous quasars.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
